User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the FollowPilot application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

subscriptionStatus.description: The current subscription status of the user (e.g., active, inactive).

Contact.title: Contact
Contact.description: Represents a contact or lead that the user is following up with.

id.description: Unique identifier for the contact entity.

Reminder.title: Reminder
Reminder.description: Represents a scheduled reminder for a contact.

id.description: Unique identifier for the reminder entity.

scheduledTime.description: Date and time when the reminder should be sent.

message.description: The message to be sent as a reminder.

channel.description: The channel through which the reminder will be sent (e.g., WhatsApp, SMS, Email).

status.description: Status of the reminder (e.g., pending, sent, seen, replied, ignored).

HistoryLog.title: HistoryLog
HistoryLog.description: Represents a historical log of reminders delivered.

id.description: Unique identifier for the history log entry.

sentTime.description: Timestamp of when the reminder was actually sent.

deliveryStatus.description: Delivery status from the provider (e.g., sent, delivered, failed).

providerResponse.description: The raw response from the messaging provider (e.g., Twilio, SendGrid).

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier of the user.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed for simplicity during development. It uses top-level collections for users, contacts, reminders, and history logs. This model is easy to understand and query. For production, a nested structure where user-specific data (contacts, reminders) is stored under `/users/{userId}` is recommended for better security and scalability. The current flat structure is a temporary measure to facilitate rapid prototyping as per the immediate debugging requirements.
